intro: Psidium molle var. robustum, commonly known as the Brazilian cherry or granadilla, is a tropical plant native to South America. It is a member of the Myrtaceae family and is characterized by its glossy, dark green leaves and showy, white to pink flowers. The plant produces small, red, edible fruits that are similar in appearance to cherries but have a tart, acidic flavor. It thrives in warm, humid climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. The plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value and as a source of fruit in both home gardens and commercial settings.
